model_output:
Comparison of Main Theoretical Perspectives on AI Approaches Mimicking Human Decision-Making Processes

The main theoretical perspectives on AI approaches mimicking human decision-making processes can be categorized as follows:

1. Turing Test approach (Turing, 1950; discussed in 2023 [1])
   - Proposes a benchmark for assessing machine intelligence based on the ability of a machine to conduct human-like conversation over a text channel. The first widely-published method dates back to 1966 with the ELIZA chatbot. 2. Normative and Descriptive Approaches (discussed in 1989 [4] and 1990 [2])
   - Normative approaches focus on mathematical correctness and effectiveness in representing and managing uncertainty in rule-based reasoning for AI. - Descriptive approaches aim to produce interpretations of probabilistic reasoning that are more compatible with human reasoning styles (1990 [2]). 3. Empirical Study of Human Strategies for Uncertain Reasoning (discussed in 1990 [2])
   - Researchers conducted empirical studies to investigate human strategies for uncertain reasoning, providing inspiration for the design of new modes of explaining probabilistic reasoning, such as qualitative belief propagation and scenario-based reasoning. 4. Universal Intelligence (discussed in 2007 [5])
   - Explores the relationship between universal intelligence, human intelligence, and other proposed definitions of machine intelligence. The paper provides an overview of the complex intellectual, social, and political history of human intelligence. References:
[1] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
[2] 1304.1082v1.pdf (1990)
[3] 3641289.pdf (2024)
[4] 1304.1083v1.pdf (1989)
[5] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
